entry.question:
**Shantiparva 27.1 a-b** *छिन्नं मूलमनर्थानां ... तस्मिन्भविष्यति*
Who will be slain at noon?
A) Yudhiṣṭhira B) Bhīma C) Arjuna D) Kṛṣṇa
entry.answer: A) Yudhiṣṭhira • Verse states "Yudhiṣṭhira the king slew Śalya" — the missing word is his name. • Bhīma and Arjuna were fighting elsewhere at that hour (cf. later verses). • Kṛṣṇa acts only as charioteer in this battle.

entry.question:
**Shantiparva 28.1 a-b** *एषा वै नैष्ठिकी बुद्धिः सर्वेषामेव ... तत्क्षिप्रं संविधीयताम्*
Who will be swiftly governed?
A) Yudhiṣṭhira B) Bhīma C) Duryodhana D) Kṛṣṇa
entry.answer: C) Duryodhana • Verse implies Duryodhana's rule is the subject of discussion. • Yudhiṣṭhira and Kṛṣṇa are allies, not rulers here. • Bhīma's role is as a warrior, not a king.

entry.question:
**Shantiparva 29.1 a-b** *इत्युक्त्वा समुदैक्षन्त ... पन्नगेश्वरम्*
Who did Vasuki address?
A) Takshaka B) Kṛṣṇa C) Bhīma D) Arjuna
entry.answer: A) Takshaka • Takshaka is the serpent king mentioned in the context. • Kṛṣṇa and Bhīma are not involved in this dialogue. • Arjuna's role is elsewhere in the Mahābhārata.

entry.question:
**Shantiparva 30.1 a-b** *नैषा वो नैष्ठिकी बुद्धिर्मता कर्तुं ... भुजङ्गमाः*
Who is the subject of the discussion about a permanent plan?
A) Takshaka B) Vasuki C) Bhīma D) Yudhiṣṭhira
entry.answer: B) Vasuki • Vasuki is the serpent king and central figure in this passage. • Takshaka is a rival, not the focus here. • Bhīma and Yudhiṣṭhira are not mentioned in this context.

entry.question:
**Shantiparva 31.1 a-b** *अनेनाहं भृशं तप्ये गुणदोषौ मदाश्रयौ*
What did the speaker endure?
A) Famine B) War C) Spiritual trials D) Political strife
entry.answer: C) Spiritual trials • The verse mentions "tapye" (suffered), implying asceticism. • Famine and war are not directly referenced. • Political strife is a later theme, not this verse.

entry.question:
**Shantiparva 34.1 a-b** *श्रुत्वा तु वचनं तेषां सर्वेषामिति चेति च | ... एलापत्रोऽब्रवीदिदम्*
Who spoke to the serpents?
A) Vasuki B) Takshaka C) Elapatra D) Kṛṣṇa
entry.answer: C) Elapatra • Elapatra is the serpent king who addresses the serpents. • Vasuki and Takshaka are other serpents, not the speaker here. • Kṛṣṇa is not involved in this dialogue.

entry.question:
**Shantiparva 35.1 a-b** *एलापत्रस्य तु वचः श्रुत्वा नागा द्विजोत्तम | सर्वे प्रहृष्टमनसः साधु साध्वित्यपूजयन्*
What did the serpents do after hearing Elapatra's words?
A) Fought B) Celebrated C) Fled D) Searched
entry.answer: B) Celebrated • "Prahṛṣṭamanaḥ" means they were delighted. • Fighting and fleeing are not mentioned. • Searching is unrelated to the context.

entry.question:
**Shantiparva 36.1 a-b** *जरत्कारुरिति प्रोक्तं यत्त्वया सूतनन्दन | इच्छाम्येतदहं तस्य ऋषेः श्रोतुं महात्मनः*
Who is the sage being referred to?
A) Vasuki B) Elapatra C) Jaraṭkāru D) Takshaka
entry.answer: C) Jaraṭkāru • The verse explicitly names Jaraṭkāru as the sage. • Vasuki and Takshaka are serpents, not sages. • Elapatra is a serpent king, not the sage here.

entry.question:
**Shantiparva 37.1 a-b** *जरेति क्षयमाहुर्वै दारुणं कारुसञ्ज्ञितम् | शरीरं कारु तस्यासीत्तत्स धीमाञ्शनैः शनैः*
What does "Kāru" refer to?
A) A serpent B) A king C) A warrior D) A sage
entry.answer: A) A serpent • "Kāru" is a term for serpents in the Mahābhārata. • The context of "dāruṇa" (terrible) aligns with serpents. • Kings and sages are not described as "dāruṇa" here.

entry.question:
**Shantiparva 38.1 a-b** *एवमुक्तः स तेजस्वी शृङ्गी कोपसमन्वितः | मृतधारं गुरुं श्रुत्वा पर्यतप्यत मन्युना*
What did the king do after hearing the news?
A) Fought B) Searched C) Searched for a solution D) Fled
entry.answer: C) Searched for a solution • "Paryatapyata" means he pondered or sought solutions. • Fighting and fleeing are not mentioned. • Searching is too vague compared to "sought a solution."
